baseline: As anarchism does not offer a fixed body of doctrine from a single particular worldview, many anarchist types and traditions exist and varieties of anarchy diverge widely.

baseline: Mutualism has been retrospectively characterised as ideologically situated between individualist and collectivist forms of anarchism.

baseline: In What Is Property? (1840), Proudhon first characterised his goal as a "third form of society, the synthesis of communism and property." Collectivist anarchism is a revolutionary socialist form of anarchism commonly associated with Mikhail Bakunin.

prompts: Collectivist anarchism arose alongside Marxism but rejected the dictatorship of
baseline: Collectivist anarchism arose alongside Marxism but rejected the dictatorship of the proletariat despite the stated Marxist goal of a collectivist stateless society.

prompts: Anarcho - communism is a theory of anarchism that advocates a communist society
baseline: Anarcho-communism is a theory of anarchism that advocates a communist society with common ownership of the means of production, held by a federal network of voluntary associations, with production and consumption based on the guiding principle "From each according to his ability, to each according to his need." Anarcho-communism developed from radical socialist currents after the French Revolution but was first formulated as such in the Italian section of the First International.

prompts: Anarcho - syndicalism is a branch of anarchism that views labour syndicates as
baseline: Anarcho-syndicalism is a branch of anarchism that views labour syndicates as a potential force for revolutionary social change, replacing capitalism and the state with a new society democratically self-managed by workers.

prompts: Individualist anarchism is a set of several traditions of thought within the anarchist movement that emphasise the individual and
baseline: Individualist anarchism is a set of several traditions of thought within the anarchist movement that emphasise the individual and their will over any kinds of external determinants.

baseline: Early influences on individualist forms of anarchism include William Godwin, Max Stirner, and Henry David Thoreau.

baseline: Through many countries, individualist anarchism attracted a small yet diverse following of Bohemian artists and intellectuals as well as young anarchist outlaws in what became known as illegalism and individual reclamation.

baseline: Anarchism has continued to generate many philosophies and movements, at times eclectic, drawing upon various sources and combining disparate concepts to create new philosophical approaches.

baseline: Its publicity has also led more scholars in fields such as anthropology and history to engage with the anarchist movement, although contemporary anarchism favours actions over academic theory.

baseline: While theorists and activists have established "relatively stable constellations of anarchist principles", there is no consensus on which principles are core and commentators describe multiple anarchisms, rather than a singular anarchism, in which common principles are shared between schools of anarchism while each group prioritizes those principles differently.

baseline: In contrast with the big-A anarchism of the classical era, the newly coined term small-a anarchism signals their tendency not to base their thoughts and actions on classical-era anarchism or to refer to classical anarchists such as Peter Kropotkin and Pierre-Joseph Proudhon to justify their opinions.

baseline: As anarchism is a philosophy that embodies many diverse attitudes, tendencies, and schools of thought, disagreement over questions of values, ideology, and tactics is common.

baseline: The compatibility of capitalism, nationalism, and religion with anarchism is widely disputed, and anarchism enjoys complex relationships with ideologies such as communism, collectivism, Marxism, and trade unionism.

baseline: Objection to the state and its institutions is a sine qua non of anarchism.

baseline: A historical current that arose and flourished during 1890 and 1920 within anarchism was free love.

baseline: During the second half of the 20th century, anarchism intermingled with the second wave of feminism, radicalising some currents of the feminist movement and being influenced as well.

baseline: Les chataigniers a Osny (1888) by anarchist painter Camille Pissarro is a notable example of blending anarchism and the arts.

prompts: The most common critique of anarchism is the assertion that
baseline: The most common critique of anarchism is the assertion that humans cannot self-govern and so a state is necessary for human survival.

baseline: Philosopher Bertrand Russell supported this critique, stating that "eace and war, tariffs, regulations of sanitary conditions and the sale of noxious drugs, the preservation of a just system of distribution: these, among others, are functions which could hardly be performed in a community in which there was no central government." Another common criticism of anarchism is that it fits a world of isolation in which only the small enough entities can be self-governing; a response would be that major anarchist thinkers advocated anarchist federalism.

prompts: Another criticism of anarchism is the belief that it is inherently unstable : that an anarchist society would inevitably evolve back into a
baseline: Another criticism of anarchism is the belief that it is inherently unstable: that an anarchist society would inevitably evolve back into a state.

baseline: Fiala composed a list of common arguments against anarchism which includes critiques such as that anarchism is innately related to violence and destruction, not only in the pragmatic world, such as at protests, but in the world of ethics as well.

baseline: The third argument is that anarchism is self-contradictory as a ruling theory that has no ruling theory.

prompts: Anarchism also calls for collective action whilst endorsing the autonomy of
baseline: Anarchism also calls for collective action whilst endorsing the autonomy of the individual, hence no collective action can be taken.

baseline: Philosophical anarchism has met the criticism of members of academia following the release of pro-anarchist books such as A.

baseline: Edmundson says that while the individual does not owe the state a duty of obedience, this does not imply that anarchism is the inevitable conclusion and the state is still morally legitimate.

prompts: In The Problem of Political Authority , Michael Huemer defends philosophical anarchism ,
baseline: In The Problem of Political Authority, Michael Huemer defends philosophical anarchism, claiming that "political authority is a moral illusion."

prompts: One of the earliest criticisms is that anarchism defies and fails to
baseline: One of the earliest criticisms is that anarchism defies and fails to understand the biological inclination to authority.

prompts: Classical anarchism has been criticised for relying too heavily on
baseline: Classical anarchism has been criticised for relying too heavily on the belief that the abolition of the state will lead to human cooperation prospering.

baseline: Friedrich Engels, considered to be one of the principal founders of Marxism, criticised anarchism's anti-authoritarianism as inherently counter-revolutionary because in his view a revolution is by itself authoritarian.

baseline: Academic John Molyneux writes in his book Anarchism: A Marxist Criticism that "anarchism cannot win", believing that it lacks the ability to properly implement its ideas.

baseline: The Marxist criticism of anarchism is that it has a utopian character because all individuals should have anarchist views and values.

baseline: Anarchic attitudes were also articulated by tragedians and philosophers in Greece.

baseline: Many scholars reject anarcho-capitalism as a misunderstanding of anarchist principles.

baseline: Anarcho-communists, who drew inspiration from the 1871 Paris Commune, advocated for free federation and for the distribution of goods according to one's needs.

baseline: In China, small groups of students imported the humanistic pro-science version of anarcho-communism.

baseline: In Latin America, Argentina was a stronghold for anarcho-syndicalism, where it became the most prominent left-wing ideology.

prompts: Anarchism 's emphasis on anti - capitalism , egalitarianism , and for the extension of community and individuality sets it apart from
baseline: Anarchism's emphasis on anti-capitalism, egalitarianism, and for the extension of community and individuality sets it apart from anarcho-capitalism and other types of economic libertarianism.

prompts: Anarcho - communism is a theory of anarchism that advocates a communist society
baseline: Anarcho-communism is a theory of anarchism that advocates a communist society with common ownership of the means of production, held by a federal network of voluntary associations, with production and consumption based on the guiding principle "From each according to his ability, to each according to his need." Anarcho-communism developed from radical socialist currents after the French Revolution but was first formulated as such in the Italian section of the First International.

prompts: Anarcho - syndicalism is a branch of anarchism that views labour syndicates as
baseline: Anarcho-syndicalism is a branch of anarchism that views labour syndicates as a potential force for revolutionary social change, replacing capitalism and the state with a new society democratically self-managed by workers.

prompts: The basic principles of anarcho - syndicalism are direct action ,
baseline: The basic principles of anarcho-syndicalism are direct action, workers' solidarity and workers' self-management.

prompts: Lawrence Jarach ( left ) and John Zerzan ( right ) are two prominent contemporary
baseline: Lawrence Jarach (left) and John Zerzan (right) are two prominent contemporary anarchist authors, with Zerzan being a prominent voice within anarcho-primitivism and Jarach a notable advocate of post-left anarchy.

prompts: Gender equality can be a common principle , although it ranks as a higher
baseline: Gender equality can be a common principle, although it ranks as a higher priority to anarcha-feminists than anarcho-communists.

prompts: Anarcho - pacifists advocate for non - violence means to achieve their
baseline: Anarcho-pacifists advocate for non-violence means to achieve their stateless, nonviolent ends.

prompts: Black bloc protesters parading anarcho -
baseline: Black bloc protesters parading anarcho-communism imagery such as the motto "No War but the Class War"

prompts: Phenomena such as civilisation , technology ( e.g. within anarcho - primitivism ) , and the democratic process may be sharply criticised within some anarchist
baseline: Phenomena such as civilisation, technology (e.g. within anarcho-primitivism), and the democratic process may be sharply criticised within some anarchist tendencies and simultaneously lauded in others.

prompts: Anarcho - primitivists in particular argue that humans were better off in a state of nature in small tribes living close to the
baseline: Anarcho-primitivists in particular argue that humans were better off in a state of nature in small tribes living close to the land, while anarchists in general argue that the negatives of state organization, such as hierarchies, monopolies and inequality, outweigh the benefits.

prompts: Contemporary anarchism within the history of anarchism is the period of
baseline: Contemporary anarchism within the history of anarchism is the period of the anarchist movement continuing from the end of World War II and into the present.

prompts: While theorists and activists have established " relatively stable constellations of anarchist principles " , there is no consensus on
baseline: While theorists and activists have established "relatively stable constellations of anarchist principles", there is no consensus on which principles are core and commentators describe multiple "anarchisms" (rather than a singular "anarchism") in which common principles are shared between schools of anarchism while each group prioritizes those principles differently.

prompts: New currents which emerged within contemporary anarchism include post - anarchism
baseline: New currents which emerged within contemporary anarchism include post-anarchism and post-left anarchy.

prompts: New anarchism is a term that has been notably used by several authors
baseline: New anarchism is a term that has been notably used by several authors to describe the most recent reinvention of the anarchist thought and practice.

prompts: What distinguishes the new anarchism of today from the new anarchism of the 1960s and 1970s , or from the work of Anglo - American based authors such as
baseline: What distinguishes the new anarchism of today from the new anarchism of the 1960s and 1970s, or from the work of Anglo-American based authors such as Murray Bookchin, Alex Comfort, Paul Goodman, Herbert Read and Colin Ward, is its emphasis on the global perspective.

prompts: Essays on new anarchism include David Graeber 's " New Anarchists " and Andrej Grubačić 's " Towards Another Anarchism " ; other authors have criticized the term for
baseline: Essays on new anarchism include David Graeber's "New Anarchists" and Andrej Grubačić's "Towards Another Anarchism"; other authors have criticized the term for being too vague.

prompts: Contemporary news coverage which emphasizes black bloc demonstrations has reinforced anarchism 's historical
baseline: Contemporary news coverage which emphasizes black bloc demonstrations has reinforced anarchism's historical association with chaos and violence; however, its publicity has also led more scholars to engage with the anarchist movement, although contemporary anarchism favours actions over academic theory.

prompts: Anarchism was influential in the counterculture of the 1960s and anarchists actively participated in the protests
baseline: Anarchism was influential in the counterculture of the 1960s and anarchists actively participated in the protests of 1968 involving students and workers revolts.

prompts: The relationship between anarchism and punk as well as squatting has carried on
baseline: The relationship between anarchism and punk as well as squatting has carried on into the 21st century.

prompts: In Infinitely Demanding , Simon Critchley wrote : " There
baseline: In Infinitely Demanding, Simon Critchley wrote: "There is no doubt that 60s anarchism was libertarian and linked to the sexual revolution, liberation of the erotic instincts and what Herbert Marcuse called 'nonrepressive sublimation'.

prompts: Yet , contemporary anarchism can be seen as a powerful
baseline: Yet, contemporary anarchism can be seen as a powerful critique of the pseudo-libertarianism of contemporary neo-liberalism, where the sexual revolution has turned the culture industry into the sex industry – ask yourself, is there today anything less transgressive and more normalizing than pornography? One might say that contemporary anarchism is about responsibility, whether sexual, ecological or socio-economic; it flows from an experience of conscience about the manifold ways in which the West ravages the rest; it is an ethical outrage at the yawning inequality, impoverishment and disenfranchisment that is so palpable locally and globally."

prompts: Since the revival of anarchism in the mid-20th century , a number of new movements and schools of thought emerged , well documented
baseline: Since the revival of anarchism in the mid-20th century, a number of new movements and schools of thought emerged, well documented in Robert Graham's Anarchism: A Documentary History of Libertarian Ideas, Volume Two: The Emergence of the New Anarchism (1939–1977).

prompts: The American civil rights movement and the movement in opposition to the Vietnam War also contributed to the revival
baseline: The American civil rights movement and the movement in opposition to the Vietnam War also contributed to the revival of North American anarchism.

prompts: European anarchism of the late 20th century drew much of its
baseline: European anarchism of the late 20th century drew much of its strength from the labour movement and both have incorporated animal rights activism.

prompts: Anarchist anthropologist David Graeber and anarchist historian Andrej Grubačić have posited a rupture between
baseline: Anarchist anthropologist David Graeber and anarchist historian Andrej Grubačić have posited a rupture between generations of anarchism, with those "who often still have not shaken the sectarian habits" of the 19th century contrasted with the younger activists who are "much more informed, among other elements, by indigenous, feminist, ecological and cultural-critical ideas" and who by the turn of the 21st century formed "by far the majority" of anarchists.

prompts: Around the turn of the 21st century , anarchism grew in popularity and
baseline: Around the turn of the 21st century, anarchism grew in popularity and influence as part of the anti-war, anti-capitalist and anti-globalisation movements.

prompts: Platformism is an important current
baseline: Platformism is an important current in international anarchism.

prompts: Noam Chomsky stated that anarcho - syndicalism , a classical anarchist school of thought that remains popular and relevant
baseline: Noam Chomsky stated that anarcho-syndicalism, a classical anarchist school of thought that remains popular and relevant to contemporary anarchism, is "highly relevant to advanced industrial societies".

prompts: Anarchism continues to generate many philosophies and movements , at times eclectic , drawing upon various sources
baseline: Anarchism continues to generate many philosophies and movements, at times eclectic, drawing upon various sources and syncretic, combining disparate concepts to create new philosophical approaches.

prompts: Self - avowed anarchist scholars such as David Graeber and Andrej Grubačić have written on trends within
baseline: Self-avowed anarchist scholars such as David Graeber and Andrej Grubačić have written on trends within contemporary anarchism both individually and in collaboration.

prompts: Writing together , their emphasis is upon a " global revolutionary movement " finding roots in anarchism
baseline: Writing together, their emphasis is upon a "global revolutionary movement" finding roots in anarchism as opposed to Marxism, and a new generation "much more interested in developing new forms of practice than arguing about the finer points of ideology." Using the phrase "the new anarchists", Graeber elaborates upon practice with regard to globalization, "a 'new language' of civil disobedience", direct democracy, and prefigurative politics.

prompts: Using the phrase another anarchism , Grubačić situates contemporary anarchism in
baseline: Using the phrase another anarchism, Grubačić situates contemporary anarchism in terms of its historical roots, and emphasizes its "anti-sectarian" nature, rejection of vanguardism, internationalism, decentralization, and direct democracy.

prompts: Using the phrase new anarchism , political scientist Leonard Williams seeks out an "
baseline: Using the phrase new anarchism, political scientist Leonard Williams seeks out an "anarchist metaphysic" of contemporary anarchism and emphasizes its anti-authoritarianism, pluralism, and its "theory of practice." While stipulating a use of the phrase new anarchism that does "not specifically refer to David Graeber's use of the term here in his New Left Review article 'The New Anarchists'", Teoman Gee decries the associations of the phrase with anarchist practices that are anti-historical, polemical, or associated with superficial lifestyle anarchism.

prompts: Post - anarchism is a revision of
baseline: Post-anarchism is a revision of classical anarchism sometimes through the influence of post-structuralists such as Jean Baudrillard, Gilles Deleuze, Michel Foucault, and Jacques Lacan.

prompts: Post - anarchism is a contested term , with its prefix " post " referring to post -
baseline: Post-anarchism is a contested term, with its prefix "post" referring to post-structuralism and/or postmodernism, which themselves are contested terms.

prompts: The postmodern aspect of post - anarchism involves rejection of universal
baseline: The postmodern aspect of post-anarchism involves rejection of universal values and grand theories in favor of plurality and hybridity.

prompts: Philosopher Benjamin Franks identified three types of post - anarchism : ( 1 ) Lyotardian Postanarchism , which proposes replacing classical anarchist ( revolutionary ) tactics with those of post - structuralists ; ( 2 ) redemptive postanarchism , to incorporate post - structural theory into existing anarchist practices ; and ( 3 ) postmodern anarchism , which applies anarchist approaches to
baseline: Philosopher Benjamin Franks identified three types of post-anarchism: (1) Lyotardian Postanarchism, which proposes replacing classical anarchist (revolutionary) tactics with those of post-structuralists; (2) redemptive postanarchism, to incorporate post-structural theory into existing anarchist practices; and (3) postmodern anarchism, which applies anarchist approaches to globalized oppressions of the late 21st century.

prompts: Critics of post - anarchism argue that it ignores principles of class
baseline: Critics of post-anarchism argue that it ignores principles of class warfare and economic exploitation, not producing political action.

prompts: Duane Rousselle and Saul Newman have advanced a psychoanalytic post
baseline: Duane Rousselle and Saul Newman have advanced a psychoanalytic post-anarchism inspired by the writings of Jacques Lacan.

prompts: Post - left anarchy is a recent current in anarchist thought that promotes a
baseline: Post-left anarchy is a recent current in anarchist thought that promotes a critique of anarchism's relationship to traditional left-wing politics, such as its emphasis on class struggle, social revolution, labor unions, the working class, and identity politics.

prompts: Gender equality can be a common principle , although it ranks as a higher
baseline: Gender equality can be a common principle, although it ranks as a higher priority to anarcha-feminists than anarcho-communists.

prompts: In the United Kingdom during the 1970s , this was associated with the punk
baseline: In the United Kingdom during the 1970s, this was associated with the punk rock movement as exemplified by bands such as Crass (pioneers of the anarcho-punk subgenre) and the Sex Pistols.

prompts: Other active anarcho - syndicalist movements include the CNT –
baseline: Other active anarcho-syndicalist movements include the CNT–AIT in France, the Union Sindicale Italiana in Italy, the Central Organisation of the Workers of Sweden and the Swedish Anarcho-syndicalist Youth Federation in Sweden, the Workers Solidarity Alliance in the United States and the Solidarity Federation in the United Kingdom.

prompts: The revolutionary industrial unionist Industrial Workers of the World claiming 10,000 paying members
baseline: The revolutionary industrial unionist Industrial Workers of the World claiming 10,000 paying members and the International Workers' Association, an anarcho-syndicalist successor to the First International, also remain active.

prompts: Today , there are organisations inspired by
baseline: Today, there are organisations inspired by Dielo Truda's Organizational Platform of the General Union of Anarchists (Draft) in many countries, including Federación Anarco-Comunista de Argentina and Línea Anarco-Comunista in Argentina, the Melbourne Anarchist Communist Group and Sydney Anarchist Communist Trajectory in Australia, Fórum do Anarquismo Organizado in Brazil, Common Cause (Ontario) and Union Communiste Libertaire (Quebec) in Canada, Federación Comunista Libertaria and Organización Comunista Libertaria (OCL) in Chile,Alternative Libertaire and Organisation Communiste Libertaire in France, Federazione dei Comunisti Anarchici in Italy, Alianza de los Comunistas Libertarios in Mexico, Motmakt in Norway, Unión Socialista Libertaria in Peru, the Zabalaza Anarchist Communist Front in South Africa, Collective Action in the United Kingdom, Common Struggle/Lucha Común in the United States and the Revolutionary Confederation of Anarcho-Syndicalists by the name of N.

prompts: Noam Chomsky stated that anarcho - syndicalism , a classical anarchist school of thought that remains popular and relevant
baseline: Noam Chomsky stated that anarcho-syndicalism, a classical anarchist school of thought that remains popular and relevant to contemporary anarchism, is "highly relevant to advanced industrial societies".

prompts: CrimethInc , which is influenced by situationism , anarcho - punk , and green anarchy , argues for a DIY
baseline: CrimethInc, which is influenced by situationism, anarcho-punk, and green anarchy, argues for a DIY folk approach to everyday life, including refusal of work, escaping gender roles, and straight edge lifestyle.

prompts: First published by Harper and
baseline: First published by Harper and Row in 1970 as In Defense of Anarchism: With a Reply to Jeffrey H.

prompts: In Part III , " Beyond the Legitimate State " , Wolff arrives at the foreshadowed
baseline: In Part III, "Beyond the Legitimate State", Wolff arrives at the foreshadowed conclusion that because autonomy and the legitimacy of state power are incompatible, one must either embrace anarchism or surrender one's autonomy, as Thomas Hobbes proposed, to whichever authority seems strongest at the time.

prompts: Wolff 's premising of " the State " and the " autonomous individual " as fixed , given entities
baseline: Wolff's premising of "the State" and the "autonomous individual" as fixed, given entities has been criticised by Thomas Martin in Social Anarchism as reflecting "basic assumptions arising from Renaissance humanism, Enlightenment liberalism, and the alliance of capitalism and central authority that has marked the industrial era." Such notions have been critiqued by late-20th-century currents in anarchist thought such as post-left anarchy, insurrectionary anarchism and particularly post-anarchism.

prompts: The book was well received not only in academic philosophy and in traditional anarchist circles , but also by anarcho - capitalists such as Murray Rothbard , whose letters of praise " chagrined " Wolff ,
baseline: The book was well received not only in academic philosophy and in traditional anarchist circles, but also by anarcho-capitalists such as Murray Rothbard, whose letters of praise "chagrined" Wolff, who was shocked to have a position that was consonant to those he thought of as "right-wingers".

prompts: Anarchism is generally defined as the political philosophy which holds the state to
baseline: Anarchism is generally defined as the political philosophy which holds the state to be undesirable, unnecessary and harmful as well as opposing authority and hierarchical organization in the conduct of human relations.

prompts: Proponents of anarchism , known as anarchists , advocate stateless societies based
baseline: Proponents of anarchism, known as anarchists, advocate stateless societies based on non-hierarchical voluntary associations.

prompts: While anarchism holds the state to be undesirable , unnecessary and harmful , opposition to the state is not its central
baseline: While anarchism holds the state to be undesirable, unnecessary and harmful, opposition to the state is not its central or sole definition.

prompts: Anarchism can entail opposing authority or
baseline: Anarchism can entail opposing authority or hierarchy in the conduct of all human relations.

prompts: Anarchism is often considered a far - left ideology and much
baseline: Anarchism is often considered a far-left ideology and much of its economics and legal philosophy reflect anti-authoritarian interpretations of communism, collectivism, syndicalism, mutualism, or participatory economics.

prompts: As anarchism does not offer a fixed body of doctrine
baseline: As anarchism does not offer a fixed body of doctrine from a single particular worldview, many anarchist types and traditions exist, not all of which are mutually exclusive.

prompts: Strains of anarchism have often been divided into the categories
baseline: Strains of anarchism have often been divided into the categories of social and individualist anarchism or similar dual classifications.

prompts: Other classifications may add mutualism as a third category while some consider it part of
baseline: Other classifications may add mutualism as a third category while some consider it part of individualist anarchism and others regard it to be part of social anarchism.

prompts: Several years earlier in 1888 , the individualist anarchist Benjamin Tucker included the full text
baseline: Several years earlier in 1888, the individualist anarchist Benjamin Tucker included the full text of a "Socialistic Letter" by Ernest Lesigne in his essay on "State Socialism and Anarchism".

prompts: As an anti - capitalist and libertarian socialist philosophy , anarchism is placed on the far
baseline: As an anti-capitalist and libertarian socialist philosophy, anarchism is placed on the far-left of the political spectrum and much of its economics and legal philosophy reflect anti-authoritarian interpretations of left-wing politics such as communism, collectivism, syndicalism, mutualism, or participatory economics.

prompts: As anarchism does not offer a fixed body of doctrine
baseline: As anarchism does not offer a fixed body of doctrine from a single particular worldview, many anarchist types and traditions exist and varieties of anarchy diverge widely.

prompts: As a result , anarchist schools of thought can differ fundamentally yet maintain
baseline: As a result, anarchist schools of thought can differ fundamentally yet maintain the common tenets of anarchism, supporting anything from extreme individualism to complete collectivism.

prompts: Strains of anarchism have often been divided into the categories
baseline: Strains of anarchism have often been divided into the categories of social and individualist anarchism, or similar dual classifications.

prompts: Nonetheless , anti - capitalism is considered a necessary element
baseline: Nonetheless, anti-capitalism is considered a necessary element of anarchism by most anarchists.

prompts: Due to the many anarchist schools of thought , anarchism can be divided into two or
baseline: Due to the many anarchist schools of thought, anarchism can be divided into two or more categories, the most used being individualist anarchism vs. social anarchism.

prompts: Other categorizations may include green anarchism and/or left and right anarchism
baseline: Other categorizations may include green anarchism and/or left and right anarchism.

prompts: Terms like anarcho - socialism or socialist anarchism can also be used as synonymous for
baseline: Terms like anarcho-socialism or socialist anarchism can also be used as synonymous for social anarchism, but this is rejected by most anarchists since they generally consider themselves socialists of the libertarian tradition and are seen as unnecessary and confusing when not used as synonymous for libertarian or stateless socialism vis-à-vis authoritarian or state socialism.

prompts: Anarchism has been historically identified with the socialist and anti - capitalist movement , with the main divide being between anti - market anarchists who support some form of
baseline: Anarchism has been historically identified with the socialist and anti-capitalist movement, with the main divide being between anti-market anarchists who support some form of decentralised economic planning and pro-market anarchists who support free-market socialism, therefore such terms are mainly used by anarcho-capitalism theorists and scholars who recognize anarcho-capitalism to differentiate between the two.

prompts: For similar reasons , anarchists also reject categorizations such as
baseline: For similar reasons, anarchists also reject categorizations such as left and right anarchism (anarcho-capitalism and national-anarchism), seeing anarchism as a libertarian socialist and radical left-wing or far-left ideology.

prompts: While most anarcho - capitalists theorists and scholars divide anarchism into social
baseline: While most anarcho-capitalists theorists and scholars divide anarchism into social anarchism vis-à-vis individualist anarchism meaning socialism vs. capitalism, seeing the two as mutually exclusive although accepting all anarchist schools of thought under panarchy on the basis of voluntaryism, anarchist theorists and scholars opposing to anarcho-capitalism reject this, not seeing them as a struggle between socialism and capitalism or as mutually exclusive, but instead as complementary, with their differences mainly being based on the means to attain anarchy, rather than on their ends, arguing against certain anarcho-capitalist theorists and scholars who see individualist anarchism as pro-capitalist and reiterating that anarchism as a whole is socialist, meaning libertarian and anti-statist socialism.

prompts: Notwithstanding the name , collectivist anarchism is also seen as a blend
baseline: Notwithstanding the name, collectivist anarchism is also seen as a blend of individualism and collectivism.

prompts: Anarchism is generally considered an individualist philosophy , opposing all forms of
baseline: Anarchism is generally considered an individualist philosophy, opposing all forms of authoritarian collectivism, but one which does see the individual or the community as complementary rather than mutually exclusive, with anarcho-communism and social anarchism in particular most rejecting the individualist–collectivist dichotomy.

prompts: Finally , social anarchism is a term used in the United
baseline: Finally, social anarchism is a term used in the United States to refer to Murray Bookchin's circle and its omonymous journal.

prompts: Schools of thought such as anarcha - feminism , anarcho - pacifism , anarcho - primitivism , anarcho - transhumanism and green anarchism have different economic views

baseline: As such, Chartier has argued that anarcho-capitalists should reject capitalism and call themselves free-market advocates, writing that "it makes sense for  to name what they oppose "capitalism." Doing so calls attention to the freedom movement's radical roots, emphasizes the value of understanding society as an alternative to the state, underscores the fact that proponents of freedom object to non-aggressive as well as aggressive restraints on liberty, ensures that advocates of freedom aren't confused with people who use market rhetoric to prop up an unjust status quo, and expresses solidarity between defenders of freed markets and workers—as well as ordinary people around the world who use "capitalism" as a short-hand label for the world-system that constrains their freedom and stunts their lives".

baseline: Yet, contemporary anarchism can be seen as a powerful critique of the pseudo-libertarianism of contemporary neo-liberalism, where the sexual revolution has turned the culture industry into the sex industry – ask yourself, is there today anything less transgressive and more normalizing than pornography? One might say that contemporary anarchism is about responsibility, whether sexual, ecological or socio-economic; it flows from an experience of conscience about the manifold ways in which the West ravages the rest; it is an ethical outrage at the yawning inequality, impoverishment and disenfranchisment that is so palpable locally and globally."

baseline: The postmodern aspect of post-anarchism involves rejection of universal values and grand theories in favor of plurality and hybridity.

baseline: Philosopher Benjamin Franks identified three types of post-anarchism: (1) Lyotardian Postanarchism, which proposes replacing classical anarchist (revolutionary) tactics with those of post-structuralists; (2) redemptive postanarchism, to incorporate post-structural theory into existing anarchist practices; and (3) postmodern anarchism, which applies anarchist approaches to globalized oppressions of the late 21st century.

baseline: Anarchism is generally defined as the political philosophy which holds the state to be undesirable, unnecessary and harmful as well as opposing authority and hierarchical organization in the conduct of human relations.

baseline: Proponents of anarchism, known as anarchists, advocate stateless societies based on non-hierarchical voluntary associations.

baseline: While anarchism holds the state to be undesirable, unnecessary and harmful, opposition to the state is not its central or sole definition.

baseline: Anarchism can entail opposing authority or hierarchy in the conduct of all human relations.

baseline: As anarchism does not offer a fixed body of doctrine from a single particular worldview, many anarchist types and traditions exist, not all of which are mutually exclusive.

baseline: Other classifications may add mutualism as a third category while some consider it part of individualist anarchism and others regard it to be part of social anarchism.

baseline: As an anti-capitalist and libertarian socialist philosophy, anarchism is placed on the far-left of the political spectrum and much of its economics and legal philosophy reflect anti-authoritarian interpretations of left-wing politics such as communism, collectivism, syndicalism, mutualism, or participatory economics.

baseline: As anarchism does not offer a fixed body of doctrine from a single particular worldview, many anarchist types and traditions exist and varieties of anarchy diverge widely.

baseline: As a result, anarchist schools of thought can differ fundamentally yet maintain the common tenets of anarchism, supporting anything from extreme individualism to complete collectivism.

baseline: Strains of anarchism have often been divided into the categories of social and individualist anarchism, or similar dual classifications.

baseline: Nonetheless, anti-capitalism is considered a necessary element of anarchism by most anarchists.

baseline: Due to the many anarchist schools of thought, anarchism can be divided into two or more categories, the most used being individualist anarchism vs. social anarchism.

baseline: Other categorizations may include green anarchism and/or left and right anarchism.

baseline: Terms like anarcho-socialism or socialist anarchism can also be used as synonymous for social anarchism, but this is rejected by most anarchists since they generally consider themselves socialists of the libertarian tradition and are seen as unnecessary and confusing when not used as synonymous for libertarian or stateless socialism vis-à-vis authoritarian or state socialism.

baseline: Anarchism has been historically identified with the socialist and anti-capitalist movement, with the main divide being between anti-market anarchists who support some form of decentralised economic planning and pro-market anarchists who support free-market socialism, therefore such terms are mainly used by anarcho-capitalism theorists and scholars who recognize anarcho-capitalism to differentiate between the two.

baseline: For similar reasons, anarchists also reject categorizations such as left and right anarchism (anarcho-capitalism and national-anarchism), seeing anarchism as a libertarian socialist and radical left-wing or far-left ideology.

baseline: While most anarcho-capitalists theorists and scholars divide anarchism into social anarchism vis-à-vis individualist anarchism meaning socialism vs. capitalism, seeing the two as mutually exclusive although accepting all anarchist schools of thought under panarchy on the basis of voluntaryism, anarchist theorists and scholars opposing to anarcho-capitalism reject this, not seeing them as a struggle between socialism and capitalism or as mutually exclusive, but instead as complementary, with their differences mainly being based on the means to attain anarchy, rather than on their ends, arguing against certain anarcho-capitalist theorists and scholars who see individualist anarchism as pro-capitalist and reiterating that anarchism as a whole is socialist, meaning libertarian and anti-statist socialism.

prompts: Notwithstanding the name , collectivist anarchism is also seen as a blend

prompts: Anarchism is generally considered an individualist philosophy , opposing all forms of
baseline: Anarchism is generally considered an individualist philosophy, opposing all forms of authoritarian collectivism, but one which does see the individual or the community as complementary rather than mutually exclusive, with anarcho-communism and social anarchism in particular most rejecting the individualist–collectivist dichotomy.

baseline: Finally, social anarchism is a term used in the United States to refer to Murray Bookchin's circle and its omonymous journal.

baseline: To differentiate it from individualist anarchism, anarchists prefer using social anarchism, a term used to characterize certain strides of anarchism vis-à-vis individualist anarchism, with the former focusing on the social aspect and generally being more organisational as well as supporting decentralised economic planning and the latter focusing on the individual and generally being more anti-organisational as well as supporting a free-market form of socialism, respectively, rather than seeing the two categories as mutually exclusive or as socialism vis-à-vis capitalism, leading to anarchism without adjectives.

baseline: As such, Chartier has argued that anarcho-capitalists should reject capitalism and call themselves free-market advocates, writing that "it makes sense for  to name what they oppose "capitalism." baseline: Anarchism appears in English from 1642 as anarchisme and anarchy from 1539; early English usages emphasised a sense of disorder.

baseline: Additionally, some anarchists use libertarian socialist to avoid anarchism's negative connotations and emphasise its connections with socialism.

prompts: Yet , contemporary anarchism can be seen as a powerful
baseline: Yet, contemporary anarchism can be seen as a powerful critique of the pseudo-libertarianism of contemporary neo-liberalism, where the sexual revolution has turned the culture industry into the sex industry – ask yourself, is there today anything less transgressive and more normalizing than pornography? One might say that contemporary anarchism is about responsibility, whether sexual, ecological or socio-economic; it flows from an experience of conscience about the manifold ways in which the West ravages the rest; it is an ethical outrage at the yawning inequality, impoverishment and disenfranchisment that is so palpable locally and globally."

baseline: The postmodern aspect of post-anarchism involves rejection of universal values and grand theories in favor of plurality and hybridity.

baseline: Proponents of anarchism, known as anarchists, advocate stateless societies based on non-hierarchical voluntary associations.

baseline: As anarchism does not offer a fixed body of doctrine from a single particular worldview, many anarchist types and traditions exist, not all of which are mutually exclusive.

baseline: As anarchism does not offer a fixed body of doctrine from a single particular worldview, many anarchist types and traditions exist and varieties of anarchy diverge widely.

baseline: As a result, anarchist schools of thought can differ fundamentally yet maintain the common tenets of anarchism, supporting anything from extreme individualism to complete collectivism.

baseline: Due to the many anarchist schools of thought, anarchism can be divided into two or more categories, the most used being individualist anarchism vs. social anarchism.

baseline: Other categorizations may include green anarchism and/or left and right anarchism.

baseline: Terms like anarcho-socialism or socialist anarchism can also be used as synonymous for social anarchism, but this is rejected by most anarchists since they generally consider themselves socialists of the libertarian tradition and are seen as unnecessary and confusing when not used as synonymous for libertarian or stateless socialism vis-à-vis authoritarian or state socialism.

baseline: Anarchism has been historically identified with the socialist and anti-capitalist movement, with the main divide being between anti-market anarchists who support some form of decentralised economic planning and pro-market anarchists who support free-market socialism, therefore such terms are mainly used by anarcho-capitalism theorists and scholars who recognize anarcho-capitalism to differentiate between the two.

baseline: For similar reasons, anarchists also reject categorizations such as left and right anarchism (anarcho-capitalism and national-anarchism), seeing anarchism as a libertarian socialist and radical left-wing or far-left ideology.

baseline: While most anarcho-capitalists theorists and scholars divide anarchism into social anarchism vis-à-vis individualist anarchism meaning socialism vs. capitalism, seeing the two as mutually exclusive although accepting all anarchist schools of thought under panarchy on the basis of voluntaryism, anarchist theorists and scholars opposing to anarcho-capitalism reject this, not seeing them as a struggle between socialism and capitalism or as mutually exclusive, but instead as complementary, with their differences mainly being based on the means to attain anarchy, rather than on their ends, arguing against certain anarcho-capitalist theorists and scholars who see individualist anarchism as pro-capitalist and reiterating that anarchism as a whole is socialist, meaning libertarian and anti-statist socialism.

baseline: Anarchism is generally considered an individualist philosophy, opposing all forms of authoritarian collectivism, but one which does see the individual or the community as complementary rather than mutually exclusive, with anarcho-communism and social anarchism in particular most rejecting the individualist–collectivist dichotomy.

baseline: Finally, social anarchism is a term used in the United States to refer to Murray Bookchin's circle and its omonymous journal.

baseline: To differentiate it from individualist anarchism, anarchists prefer using social anarchism, a term used to characterize certain strides of anarchism vis-à-vis individualist anarchism, with the former focusing on the social aspect and generally being more organisational as well as supporting decentralised economic planning and the latter focusing on the individual and generally being more anti-organisational as well as supporting a free-market form of socialism, respectively, rather than seeing the two categories as mutually exclusive or as socialism vis-à-vis capitalism, leading to anarchism without adjectives.

baseline: Yet, contemporary anarchism can be seen as a powerful critique of the pseudo-libertarianism of contemporary neo-liberalism, where the sexual revolution has turned the culture industry into the sex industry – ask yourself, is there today anything less transgressive and more normalizing than pornography? One might say that contemporary anarchism is about responsibility, whether sexual, ecological or socio-economic; it flows from an experience of conscience about the manifold ways in which the West ravages the rest; it is an ethical outrage at the yawning inequality, impoverishment and disenfranchisment that is so palpable locally and globally."

baseline: The postmodern aspect of post-anarchism involves rejection of universal values and grand theories in favor of plurality and hybridity.

baseline: As a result, anarchist schools of thought can differ fundamentally yet maintain the common tenets of anarchism, supporting anything from extreme individualism to complete collectivism.

baseline: Due to the many anarchist schools of thought, anarchism can be divided into two or more categories, the most used being individualist anarchism vs. social anarchism.

baseline: Other categorizations may include green anarchism and/or left and right anarchism.

baseline: Terms like anarcho-socialism or socialist anarchism can also be used as synonymous for social anarchism, but this is rejected by most anarchists since they generally consider themselves socialists of the libertarian tradition and are seen as unnecessary and confusing when not used as synonymous for libertarian or stateless socialism vis-à-vis authoritarian or state socialism.

baseline: Anarchism has been historically identified with the socialist and anti-capitalist movement, with the main divide being between anti-market anarchists who support some form of decentralised economic planning and pro-market anarchists who support free-market socialism, therefore such terms are mainly used by anarcho-capitalism theorists and scholars who recognize anarcho-capitalism to differentiate between the two.

baseline: For similar reasons, anarchists also reject categorizations such as left and right anarchism (anarcho-capitalism and national-anarchism), seeing anarchism as a libertarian socialist and radical left-wing or far-left ideology.

baseline: While most anarcho-capitalists theorists and scholars divide anarchism into social anarchism vis-à-vis individualist anarchism meaning socialism vs. capitalism, seeing the two as mutually exclusive although accepting all anarchist schools of thought under panarchy on the basis of voluntaryism, anarchist theorists and scholars opposing to anarcho-capitalism reject this, not seeing them as a struggle between socialism and capitalism or as mutually exclusive, but instead as complementary, with their differences mainly being based on the means to attain anarchy, rather than on their ends, arguing against certain anarcho-capitalist theorists and scholars who see individualist anarchism as pro-capitalist and reiterating that anarchism as a whole is socialist, meaning libertarian and anti-statist socialism.

prompts: Notwithstanding the name , collectivist anarchism is also seen as a blend

baseline: Anarchism is generally considered an individualist philosophy, opposing all forms of authoritarian collectivism, but one which does see the individual or the community as complementary rather than mutually exclusive, with anarcho-communism and social anarchism in particular most rejecting the individualist–collectivist dichotomy.

baseline: Finally, social anarchism is a term used in the United States to refer to Murray Bookchin's circle and its omonymous journal.

baseline: To differentiate it from individualist anarchism, anarchists prefer using social anarchism, a term used to characterize certain strides of anarchism vis-à-vis individualist anarchism, with the former focusing on the social aspect and generally being more organisational as well as supporting decentralised economic planning and the latter focusing on the individual and generally being more anti-organisational as well as supporting a free-market form of socialism, respectively, rather than seeing the two categories as mutually exclusive or as socialism vis-à-vis capitalism, leading to anarchism without adjectives.

baseline: Additionally, some anarchists use libertarian socialist to avoid anarchism's negative connotations and emphasise its connections with socialism.

baseline: Drawing from mutualism, Mikhail Bakunin founded collectivist anarchism and entered the International Workingmen's Association, a class worker union later known as the First International that formed in 1864 to unite diverse revolutionary currents.

baseline: With the anarchists being repressed in Russia, two new antithetical currents emerged, namely platformism and synthesis anarchism.

baseline: While having revolutionary aspirations, many forms of anarchism are not confrontational nowadays.

baseline: Anarchist schools of thought have been generally grouped into two main historical traditions, social anarchism and individualist anarchism, owing to their different origins, values and evolution.

baseline: In a chronological sense, anarchism can be segmented by the classical currents of the late 19th century and the post-classical currents (anarcha-feminism, green anarchism, and post-anarchism) developed thereafter.

baseline: Anarchism pays significant attention to moral arguments since ethics have a central role in anarchist philosophy.

baseline: In What Is Property? (1840), Proudhon first characterised his goal as a "third form of society, the synthesis of communism and property." Collectivist anarchism is a revolutionary socialist form of anarchism commonly associated with Mikhail Bakunin.

baseline: Anarcho-communism is a theory of anarchism that advocates a communist society with common ownership of the means of production, held by a federal network of voluntary associations, with production and consumption based on the guiding principle "From each according to his ability, to each according to his need." Anarcho-communism developed from radical socialist currents after the French Revolution but was first formulated as such in the Italian section of the First International.

baseline: Individualist anarchism is a set of several traditions of thought within the anarchist movement that emphasise the individual and their will over any kinds of external determinants.

baseline: Early influences on individualist forms of anarchism include William Godwin, Max Stirner, and Henry David Thoreau.

baseline: Through many countries, individualist anarchism attracted a small yet diverse following of Bohemian artists and intellectuals as well as young anarchist outlaws in what became known as illegalism and individual reclamation.

baseline: Individualist anarchism is a set of several traditions of thought within the anarchist movement that emphasise the individual and their will over any kinds of external determinants.

baseline: Through many countries, individualist anarchism attracted a small yet diverse following of Bohemian artists and intellectuals as well as young anarchist outlaws in what became known as illegalism and individual reclamation.

baseline: Late 20th century and contemporary anarchist writers (Paul Goodman, Herbert Read, and Colin Ward) intensified and expanded the anarchist critique of state education, largely focusing on the need for a system that focuses on children's creativity rather than on their ability to attain a career or participate in consumerism as part of a consumer society.

baseline: While few anarchist education institutions have survived to the modern-day, major tenets of anarchist schools, among them respect for child autonomy and relying on reasoning rather than indoctrination as a teaching method, have spread among mainstream educational institutions.

baseline: What distinguishes the new anarchism of today from the new anarchism of the 1960s and 1970s, or from the work of Anglo-American based authors such as Murray Bookchin, Alex Comfort, Paul Goodman, Herbert Read and Colin Ward, is its emphasis on the global perspective.

baseline: Contemporary news coverage which emphasizes black bloc demonstrations has reinforced anarchism's historical association with chaos and violence; however, its publicity has also led more scholars to engage with the anarchist movement, although contemporary anarchism favours actions over academic theory.

prompts: Yet , contemporary anarchism can be seen as a powerful
baseline: Yet, contemporary anarchism can be seen as a powerful critique of the pseudo-libertarianism of contemporary neo-liberalism, where the sexual revolution has turned the culture industry into the sex industry – ask yourself, is there today anything less transgressive and more normalizing than pornography? One might say that contemporary anarchism is about responsibility, whether sexual, ecological or socio-economic; it flows from an experience of conscience about the manifold ways in which the West ravages the rest; it is an ethical outrage at the yawning inequality, impoverishment and disenfranchisment that is so palpable locally and globally."

prompts: Since the revival of anarchism in the mid-20th century , a number of new movements and schools of thought emerged , well documented
baseline: Since the revival of anarchism in the mid-20th century, a number of new movements and schools of thought emerged, well documented in Robert Graham's Anarchism: A Documentary History of Libertarian Ideas, Volume Two: The Emergence of the New Anarchism (1939–1977).

baseline: European anarchism of the late 20th century drew much of its strength from the labour movement and both have incorporated animal rights activism.

baseline: Anarchist anthropologist David Graeber and anarchist historian Andrej Grubačić have posited a rupture between generations of anarchism, with those "who often still have not shaken the sectarian habits" of the 19th century contrasted with the younger activists who are "much more informed, among other elements, by indigenous, feminist, ecological and cultural-critical ideas" and who by the turn of the 21st century formed "by far the majority" of anarchists.

prompts: Around the turn of the 21st century , anarchism grew in popularity and
baseline: Around the turn of the 21st century, anarchism grew in popularity and influence as part of the anti-war, anti-capitalist and anti-globalisation movements.

baseline: Noam Chomsky stated that anarcho-syndicalism, a classical anarchist school of thought that remains popular and relevant to contemporary anarchism, is "highly relevant to advanced industrial societies".

baseline: Writing together, their emphasis is upon a "global revolutionary movement" finding roots in anarchism as opposed to Marxism, and a new generation "much more interested in developing new forms of practice than arguing about the finer points of ideology." Using the phrase "the new anarchists", Graeber elaborates upon practice with regard to globalization, "a 'new language' of civil disobedience", direct democracy, and prefigurative politics.

baseline: Using the phrase another anarchism, Grubačić situates contemporary anarchism in terms of its historical roots, and emphasizes its "anti-sectarian" nature, rejection of vanguardism, internationalism, decentralization, and direct democracy.

baseline: Using the phrase new anarchism, political scientist Leonard Williams seeks out an "anarchist metaphysic" of contemporary anarchism and emphasizes its anti-authoritarianism, pluralism, and its "theory of practice." While stipulating a use of the phrase new anarchism that does "not specifically refer to David Graeber's use of the term here in his New Left Review article 'The New Anarchists'", Teoman Gee decries the associations of the phrase with anarchist practices that are anti-historical, polemical, or associated with superficial lifestyle anarchism.

baseline: Post-anarchism is a contested term, with its prefix "post" referring to post-structuralism and/or postmodernism, which themselves are contested terms.

baseline: The postmodern aspect of post-anarchism involves rejection of universal values and grand theories in favor of plurality and hybridity.

baseline: Philosopher Benjamin Franks identified three types of post-anarchism: (1) Lyotardian Postanarchism, which proposes replacing classical anarchist (revolutionary) tactics with those of post-structuralists; (2) redemptive postanarchism, to incorporate post-structural theory into existing anarchist practices; and (3) postmodern anarchism, which applies anarchist approaches to globalized oppressions of the late 21st century.

baseline: Anarchism is generally defined as the political philosophy which holds the state to be undesirable, unnecessary and harmful as well as opposing authority and hierarchical organization in the conduct of human relations.

baseline: Proponents of anarchism, known as anarchists, advocate stateless societies based on non-hierarchical voluntary associations.

baseline: While anarchism holds the state to be undesirable, unnecessary and harmful, opposition to the state is not its central or sole definition.

baseline: Anarchism can entail opposing authority or hierarchy in the conduct of all human relations.

prompts: As anarchism does not offer a fixed body of doctrine
baseline: As anarchism does not offer a fixed body of doctrine from a single particular worldview, many anarchist types and traditions exist, not all of which are mutually exclusive.

baseline: Strains of anarchism have often been divided into the categories of social and individualist anarchism or similar dual classifications.

baseline: Other classifications may add mutualism as a third category while some consider it part of individualist anarchism and others regard it to be part of social anarchism.

baseline: As an anti-capitalist and libertarian socialist philosophy, anarchism is placed on the far-left of the political spectrum and much of its economics and legal philosophy reflect anti-authoritarian interpretations of left-wing politics such as communism, collectivism, syndicalism, mutualism, or participatory economics.

prompts: As anarchism does not offer a fixed body of doctrine
baseline: As anarchism does not offer a fixed body of doctrine from a single particular worldview, many anarchist types and traditions exist and varieties of anarchy diverge widely.

baseline: As a result, anarchist schools of thought can differ fundamentally yet maintain the common tenets of anarchism, supporting anything from extreme individualism to complete collectivism.

prompts: Strains of anarchism have often been divided into the categories
baseline: Strains of anarchism have often been divided into the categories of social and individualist anarchism, or similar dual classifications.

baseline: Nonetheless, anti-capitalism is considered a necessary element of anarchism by most anarchists.

baseline: Due to the many anarchist schools of thought, anarchism can be divided into two or more categories, the most used being individualist anarchism vs. social anarchism.

baseline: Other categorizations may include green anarchism and/or left and right anarchism.

prompts: Terms like anarcho - socialism or socialist anarchism can also be used as synonymous for
baseline: Terms like anarcho-socialism or socialist anarchism can also be used as synonymous for social anarchism, but this is rejected by most anarchists since they generally consider themselves socialists of the libertarian tradition and are seen as unnecessary and confusing when not used as synonymous for libertarian or stateless socialism vis-à-vis authoritarian or state socialism.

prompts: Anarchism has been historically identified with the socialist and anti - capitalist movement , with the main divide being between anti - market anarchists who support some form of
baseline: Anarchism has been historically identified with the socialist and anti-capitalist movement, with the main divide being between anti-market anarchists who support some form of decentralised economic planning and pro-market anarchists who support free-market socialism, therefore such terms are mainly used by anarcho-capitalism theorists and scholars who recognize anarcho-capitalism to differentiate between the two.

prompts: For similar reasons , anarchists also reject categorizations such as
baseline: For similar reasons, anarchists also reject categorizations such as left and right anarchism (anarcho-capitalism and national-anarchism), seeing anarchism as a libertarian socialist and radical left-wing or far-left ideology.

prompts: While most anarcho - capitalists theorists and scholars divide anarchism into social
baseline: While most anarcho-capitalists theorists and scholars divide anarchism into social anarchism vis-à-vis individualist anarchism meaning socialism vs. capitalism, seeing the two as mutually exclusive although accepting all anarchist schools of thought under panarchy on the basis of voluntaryism, anarchist theorists and scholars opposing to anarcho-capitalism reject this, not seeing them as a struggle between socialism and capitalism or as mutually exclusive, but instead as complementary, with their differences mainly being based on the means to attain anarchy, rather than on their ends, arguing against certain anarcho-capitalist theorists and scholars who see individualist anarchism as pro-capitalist and reiterating that anarchism as a whole is socialist, meaning libertarian and anti-statist socialism.

prompts: Notwithstanding the name , collectivist anarchism is also seen as a blend
baseline: Notwithstanding the name, collectivist anarchism is also seen as a blend of individualism and collectivism.

prompts: Anarchism is generally considered an individualist philosophy , opposing all forms of
baseline: Anarchism is generally considered an individualist philosophy, opposing all forms of authoritarian collectivism, but one which does see the individual or the community as complementary rather than mutually exclusive, with anarcho-communism and social anarchism in particular most rejecting the individualist–collectivist dichotomy.

prompts: Finally , social anarchism is a term used in the United
baseline: Finally, social anarchism is a term used in the United States to refer to Murray Bookchin's circle and its omonymous journal.

baseline: Schools of thought such as anarcha-feminism, anarcho-pacifism, anarcho-primitivism, anarcho-transhumanism and green anarchism have different economic views and can be either part of individualist anarchism or social anarchism.

prompts: To differentiate it from individualist anarchism , anarchists prefer using social anarchism
baseline: To differentiate it from individualist anarchism, anarchists prefer using social anarchism, a term used to characterize certain strides of anarchism vis-à-vis individualist anarchism, with the former focusing on the social aspect and generally being more organisational as well as supporting decentralised economic planning and the latter focusing on the individual and generally being more anti-organisational as well as supporting a free-market form of socialism, respectively, rather than seeing the two categories as mutually exclusive or as socialism vis-à-vis capitalism, leading to anarchism without adjectives.

prompts: Mutualism is seen as the middle or third category between social anarchism and individualist anarchism , although it has been considered part of both
baseline: Mutualism is seen as the middle or third category between social anarchism and individualist anarchism, although it has been considered part of both social anarchism and individualist anarchism.

prompts: From a materialist perspective , individualist anarchism is the anarchist form
baseline: From a materialist perspective, individualist anarchism is the anarchist form in the pre-capitalist and largely agrarian and merchantilist capitalism before the Industrial Revolution, during which individualist anarchism became a form of artisanal and self-employed socialism, especially in the United States.

baseline: Instead, social anarchism is anarchism in an industrial society, being the form of industrial or proletarian socialism, with post-left anarchy and its criticism of industrial technology and anti-workerism arising in a post-industrial society.

baseline: Furthermore, Malatesta has claimed that in practice, individualist and communist anarchism are almost identical and that the contention between these two schools of anarchism is a "question of verbal misunderstanding".

baseline: Anarchists such as Benjamin Tucker argued that it was "not Socialist Anarchism against Individualist Anarchism, but of Communist Socialism against Individualist Socialism".

baseline: Similarly, the view of an individualist–socialist divide is contested as individualist anarchism is largely socialistic.

baseline: Libertarian municipalist Murray Bookchin criticized individualist anarchists for opposing democracy and said majority rule is consistent with anarchism.

baseline: While preferring the term assembly rather than democracy, Bookchin has in turn been accused of municipal statism, i.e. non-anarchism.

baseline: Later, Bookchin renounced anarchism to identify himself as an advocate of communalism.

baseline: One major issue and divide between anarchism and anarcho-capitalism are the terms capitalism and socialism themselves.

baseline: While anarcho-capitalists who argue for private property which supports absentee and landlordism ownership rather than occupation and use property norms as well as the homestead principle are considered right-libertarians rather than anarchists (this is due to anarchism generally viewing any absentee ownership and ownership claims on land and natural resources as immoral and illegitimate and seeing the idea of perpetually binding original appropriation as advocated by some anarcho-capitalists as anathema to traditional schools of anarchism as well as to any moral or economic philosophy that takes equal natural rights to land and the Earth's resources as a premise), other anarcho-capitalists are closer to mutualism and are considered part of free-market anarchism which argue that a true free-market or laissez-faire system would be best served under socialism rather than capitalism.

prompts: As a whole , anarchism is seen part of the
baseline: As a whole, anarchism is seen part of the socialist tradition, with the main divide being between anti-market anarchists (most social anarchists, including anarcho-communists, anarcho-syndicalists and collectivist anarchists) who support some form of decentralised economic planning and pro-market anarchists (certain individualist anarchists, including free-market anarchists and mutualists) who support free-market socialism.

prompts: Another major issue and divide within anarchism and anarcho - capitalism is that of property
baseline: Another major issue and divide within anarchism and anarcho-capitalism is that of property, more specifically the issues of private property.

prompts: The term left anarchism , or left - wing anarchism , has been occasionally used to distinguish social
baseline: The term left anarchism, or left-wing anarchism, has been occasionally used to distinguish social anarchism from anarcho-capitalism and anti-state right-libertarian philosophies. "Left anarchists" refer to political philosophies which posit a future society in which private property is replaced by reciprocity and non-hierarchical society.

prompts: The term left anarchism is sometimes used synonymously with libertarian
baseline: The term left anarchism is sometimes used synonymously with libertarian socialism, left-libertarianism, or social anarchism.

prompts: Anarchists typically discourage the concept of left - wing theories of anarchism on grounds of redundancy and that it lends legitimacy to the
baseline: Anarchists typically discourage the concept of left-wing theories of anarchism on grounds of redundancy and that it lends legitimacy to the notion that anarchism is compatible with capitalism or nationalism.

prompts: Syndicalist Ulrike Heider categorized anarchism into left
baseline: Syndicalist Ulrike Heider categorized anarchism into left anarchism, right anarchism and green anarchism.

prompts: The term right anarchism , or right - wing anarchism , has been used to refer to
baseline: The term right anarchism, or right-wing anarchism, has been used to refer to schools of thoughts which are not generally considered part of anarchism, including anarcho-capitalism and national-anarchism.

prompts: Anarchism has a long history of opposing imperialism , both
baseline: Anarchism has a long history of opposing imperialism, both in the core nations (the colonizers) and the periphery nations (the colonized).

prompts: Historically , anarchism was supportive of the anationalist movement as well as of the Esperanto language , a language constructed to serve as
baseline: Historically, anarchism was supportive of the anationalist movement as well as of the Esperanto language, a language constructed to serve as a politically and ethnically neutral international language.

prompts: The so - called national - anarchist movement is not recognized as part of
baseline: The so-called national-anarchist movement is not recognized as part of anarchism by anarchists and scholars due to anarchism opposition to nationalism, the nation state, tribalism and neo-tribalism and national-anarchism's perceived racism and sexism, arguing that it represents a further evolution in the thinking of the radical right rather than an entirely new dimension.

prompts: While many anarchists ( especially those involved in the anti - globalization movement ) continue to see themselves
baseline: While many anarchists (especially those involved in the anti-globalization movement) continue to see themselves as a leftist movement, some thinkers and activists believe it is necessary to re-evaluate anarchism's relationship with the traditional left.

prompts: Post - leftists argue that anarchism has been weakened by its long
baseline: Post-leftists argue that anarchism has been weakened by its long attachment to contrary leftist movements and single issue causes (anti-war, anti-nuclear and so on).

baseline: As such, Chartier has argued that anarcho-capitalists should reject capitalism and call themselves free-market advocates, writing that "it makes sense for  to name what they oppose "capitalism." prompts: For Bakunin , the revolutionary archetype is found in a peasant
baseline: For Bakunin, the revolutionary archetype is found in a peasant milieu (which is presented as having longstanding insurrectionary traditions, as well as a communist archetype in its current social form—the peasant commune) and amongst educated unemployed youth, assorted marginals from all classes, brigands, robbers, the impoverished masses, and those on the margins of society who have escaped, been excluded from, or not yet subsumed in the discipline of emerging industrial work.  n short, all those whom Marx sought to include in the category of the lumpenproletariat".

prompts: The following outline is provided
baseline: The following outline is provided as an overview of and topical guide to anarchism:

prompts: Anarchism – political philosophy which holds the state to be undesirable , unnecessary and harmful , or alternatively as opposing authority and hierarchical
baseline: Anarchism – political philosophy which holds the state to be undesirable, unnecessary and harmful, or alternatively as opposing authority and hierarchical organization in the conduct of human relations.

prompts: Proponents of anarchism , known as anarchists , advocate stateless societies or
baseline: Proponents of anarchism, known as anarchists, advocate stateless societies or non-hierarchical voluntary associations.

prompts: Anarchism is a living project which has continued to evolve as
baseline: Anarchism is a living project which has continued to evolve as social conditions have changed.

prompts: Anarchism has many heterogeneous and diverse schools of thought , united by a common
baseline: Anarchism has many heterogeneous and diverse schools of thought, united by a common opposition to compulsory rule.

prompts: Anarchists creates different forms of organizations , structured around the principles
baseline: Anarchists creates different forms of organizations, structured around the principles of anarchism, to meet each other, share information, organize struggles and trace ways to spread the anarchist ideas through the world, since they understand that the only way to achieve a free and egalitarian society in the end is through equally free and egalitarian means.

prompts: Although social movements and philosophies with anarchic qualities predate anarchism , anarchism as a specific political philosophy began in 1840 with
baseline: Although social movements and philosophies with anarchic qualities predate anarchism, anarchism as a specific political philosophy began in 1840 with the publication of What Is Property? by Pierre-Joseph Proudhon.

prompts: The success of the 1917 October Revolution in Russia initiated a decline in
baseline: The success of the 1917 October Revolution in Russia initiated a decline in prominence for anarchism in the mid-20th century, roughly coinciding with the time period referred to by historians as The short twentieth century.

prompts: Since the late 1980s , anarchism has begun a gradual return
baseline: Since the late 1980s, anarchism has begun a gradual return to the world stage.

baseline: These are concepts which, although not exclusive to anarchism, are significant in historical and/or modern anarchist circles.

prompts: As the anarchist milieu is philosophically heterogeneous , there is disagreement over which
baseline: As the anarchist milieu is philosophically heterogeneous, there is disagreement over which of these concepts should play a role in anarchism.

baseline: Although social movements and philosophies with anarchic qualities predate anarchism, anarchism as a specific political philosophy began in 1840 with the publication of What Is Property? by Pierre-Joseph Proudhon.

baseline: Anarchist schools are characterized by "the belief that government is both harmful and unnecessary", but may differ fundamentally, supporting anything from extreme individualism to complete collectivism.

baseline: Formal anarchist organizational initiatives date back to the mid-19th century.

prompts: The oldest surviving anarchist organizations include
baseline: The oldest surviving anarchist organizations include Freedom Press (est. 1886) of England, the Industrial Workers of the World (est. 1905), Anarchist Black Cross (est. 1906), Central Organisation of the Workers of Sweden (est. 1910) and the Confederación Nacional del Trabajo (est. 1910) of Spain.

baseline: Anarchist organizations come in a variety of forms, largely based upon common anarchist principles of voluntary cooperation, mutual aid, and direct action.

baseline: They are also largely informed by anarchist social theory and philosophy, tending towards participation and decentralization.
